message_1: A sample of a radioactive element has a half-life of 10 days. If the initial mass of the sample was 80 grams, what will be the mass of the sample after 40 days? Use the concept of half-life calculations to solve the problem.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the half-life formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 80 grams, the half-life is 10 days, and the time elapsed is 40 days.

Final mass = 80 * (1/2)^(40 / 10)

Final mass = 80 * (1/2)^4

Final mass = 80 * (1/16)

Final mass = 5 grams

So, after 40 days, the mass of the radioactive sample will be 5 grams.
